channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Covid-19 shows no signs of going away. How do we live with the virus long term? The epidemiologist @BillHanage and the psychologist @DrSullivanATL join @apoorva_nyc on Tuesday, March 8, at 2:00 p.m. ET to answer your questions. DM them to @nytimesevents. https://t.co/qMtMTRNHMn

In less than a week, the U.S. and NATO have pushed more than 17,000 antitank weapons over the borders of Poland and Romania to Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, and other major cities. But those are only the most visible contributions. https://t.co/b3SLEy3Yoz

Ukraine turned on Monday to the International Court of Justice at The Hague — the UN's highest court — saying that "Russia must be stopped, and the court has a role in stopping it." Russia boycotted the hearing. https://t.co/HbMFetadVx

Businesses in Ukraine will be exempt from paying taxes for employees who are drafted into the military or serve in the nation’s territorial defense forces, President Volodymyr Zelensky announced as part of an effort to boost the country’s reeling economy. https://t.co/62Bp6dySe5

Despite the threat of yearslong prison terms, thousands of Russians joined antiwar rallies across the country on Sunday. The demonstrations were a striking show of pent-up anger over President Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/an9xHkeruG https://t.co/XQi6dMIeph

In Opinion
“Donald Trump and Volodymyr Zelensky both played leaders on TV shows and then became leaders in real life,” Maureen Dowd writes. “Trump tried to overturn American democracy. Zelensky tried to save Ukrainian democracy.” https://t.co/uISJWL32fV

Joint Base Andrews in Maryland was put on lockdown on Sunday when two people bypassed a security checkpoint at about the time that Vice President Kamala Harris landed there, officials said.
One of the intruders, who was armed, was apprehended. https://t.co/k4wroiGjau

The front page of The New York Times for March 7, 2022.
Follow our updates on the war in Ukraine. https://t.co/g4SiEp7fQl https://t.co/kbNSSmMAvU

Joint Base Andrews in Maryland was put on lockdown on Sunday when two people, at least one of whom was armed, bypassed security around the time Vice President Kamala Harris and four Cabinet members landed there, military officials said. https://t.co/ZagqoetAq8

Pakistani women have marched for their rights on International Women's Day every year since 2018.
Participants have faced countless threats of murder and rape, along with accusations that they receive Western funding as part of a plot to promote obscenity.https://t.co/B6hWmrvKij

“I told him ‘I love you’ and ‘We will see each other soon.’”
With most men legally prohibited from leaving Ukraine, the border serves as a painful filter, splitting families as women and children pour into Poland, Hungary and other neighboring nations. https://t.co/64hCDxePUr

Ukraine rejected a Kremlin proposal to evacuate hundreds of thousands of people to Russia, dismissing it as a cynical move by Russia to cover up the impact of its attacks and “create a television picture.”
Follow our updates. https://t.co/Za396jTE57

A group of truckers protesting Covid-19 mandates started to encircle Washington, D.C., on Sunday, but the convoy stayed in Maryland after organizers said they did not intend to drive into the nation’s capital. https://t.co/UKOUoECItG https://t.co/LHPN5A7yZD

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that Russia has failed to honor limited cease-fire agreements.
“We will punish everyone who committed atrocities in this war,” he said. “There will be no quiet place on this earth for you. Except for the grave.”https://t.co/zlLHPOIiLL

Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia described the war in Ukraine as a “moment of choice” for China. He warned of a “new arc of autocracy” threatening the global order, accusing China of giving Russia an economic lifeline from sanctions. https://t.co/qcHq6aYdBT

“Few expected such strength from our people.”
Ukrainian soldiers have been repelling a Russian attack on the port city of Mykolaiv for three days. For now, the city still isn't in Russian hands. https://t.co/6uxZ2JyldK

In less than a week, the U.S. and NATO have pushed more than 17,000 antitank weapons over the borders of Poland and Romania to Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, and other major cities. But those are only the most visible contributions. https://t.co/Dxd2PS2biU

A Ukrainian mother, her children and a family friend were killed when Russian mortar fire hit a bridge being used by refugees. "These are civilians, people who waited until the last moment,” one soldier said.
This story contains graphic images. https://t.co/1ks3M5klwE

Russian forces have pushed into the areas north and northeast of Kyiv over the past 11 days in an effort to encircle and capture the city. Here’s a map tracking Russia’s advance toward the capital: https://t.co/3uPz2lfh8e https://t.co/lUh5c4OeJF

A Russian cruise missile attack struck an airport in western Ukraine, some 100 miles from the capital, Kyiv, on Sunday. Videos verified by The New York Times show what are likely land attack Kalibr cruise missiles flying toward Vinnytsia Airport. https://t.co/FH2UFKHMtG

Covid-19 shows no signs of going away. How do we live with the virus long term? The epidemiologist @BillHanage and the psychologist @DrSullivanATL join @apoorva_nyc on Tuesday, March 8, at 2:00 p.m. ET to answer your questions. DM them to @nytimesevents. https://t.co/mUCUXfebyx

TikTok said it would suspend livestreaming and new content being uploaded from Russia as it reviews the country’s new law on “fake news.” The law appears to target media outlets that don’t hew to the Kremlin’s line on the invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/2TxsDN3iIP

Netflix will suspend its service in Russia “given the circumstances on the ground,” the company said, joining a number of others that have recently decided to cease services or business in Russia.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/fAHYIP9EtP

A bell tolled in Yavoriv, Ukraine, on Sunday as soldiers carried the coffin of Senior Sgt. Yevhen Verveyko, who was killed in an artillery strike four days after the war began. The 27-year-old sergeant is the first of the town’s soldiers to die in the war. https://t.co/bcUGMJ32kY

The evacuation of the besieged city of Mariupol, Ukraine, was canceled again after the mayor accused Russian forces of violating a cease-fire.
Follow updates on the Russian invasion of Ukraine: https://t.co/7260nC71Ol

A New York Times team witnessed the moment that civilians were fired upon in Irpin, Ukraine, just outside Kyiv. (This video contains scenes of graphic violence.) https://t.co/ukdsv7ZfFH https://t.co/Sv6IyYBGcU

In Opinion "If China announced that, rather than staying neutral, it was joining the economic boycott of Russia," writes Thomas Friedman, "it might shake Vladimir Putin enough to stop this vicious war." https://t.co/UyTWEG0PWo
The invasion of Ukraine has shown that President Vladimir Putin sees Europe’s borders as open to being redrawn by force. And few places feel more vulnerable than Moldova. https://t.co/zFig61wrVC

Thousands of Russians joined antiwar rallies across the country on Sunday in a striking show of the pent-up anger in Russian society about President Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/0vfroU59Kj

Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel traveled to Moscow with his national security adviser and other officials on Saturday to meet with President Vladimir Putin of Russia, according to Israeli and Russian officials. https://t.co/cZJMSW41Qd

The volume of Ukraine war content on TikTok far outweighs what's on other social networks. Much of it is unverified — for example, several videos that claimed to show present-day Ukraine actually use audio from a 2020 explosion in Beirut, Lebanon. https://t.co/r7pI7hYyai

On Sunday, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, visiting Moldova, said the United States was exploring the idea of supplying jets to Poland should Warsaw choose to send its own to Ukraine. https://t.co/0eVkNvPwyx
About two-thirds of Ukraine’s population of 44 million people lived in cities before Russia’s invasion began. Now many urban areas are in the cross hairs of war. https://t.co/iKOZ8jkMyp

Analysts are debating whether the Russian leader’s ambitions and appetite for risk have been altered by his long-held Covid bubble, or by his urgency to secure a legacy, or both. https://t.co/sKzgpyTDuI

Ten days into the war, Russia’s continued shelling near protected escape routes for Ukrainian civilians has made clear that President Vladimir Putin has decided to hammer civilian infrastructure and pulverize basic services in a sustained assault. https://t.co/1fEuk3Z0lg
In a few frantic days, the West abandoned traditional tactics and instead isolated Russia with unparalleled sanctions and penalties. Here's how it happened. https://t.co/nSVYQ6Fqva

Berlin has become a major hub for refugees from Ukraine, welcoming them with an outpouring of help. The response stirs memories of both bright and dark chapters of German history. https://t.co/ChI980IWcY

Kherson, in southern Ukraine, was the first major city to fall to Russian forces. On Saturday, street protests presented a challenge to the new authority there. Here's what one of our reporters in Ukraine saw on the ground. https://t.co/BfdKOcXidT

Senior U.S. officials are traveling to Venezuela on Saturday to meet with the government of President Nicolás Maduro as the Biden administration steps up efforts to separate Russia from its remaining allies amid a widening standoff over Ukraine. https://t.co/3SsZX3qTaI

Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, said Saturday that it would continue to buy Russian crude oil to feed into its refineries and supply customers with gasoline and diesel but would donate any profits to a fund dedicated to “the people of Ukraine.” https://t.co/QBNCs6aKEP

Mastercard and Visa announced on Saturday that they would suspend operations in Russia, essentially severing cardholders there from transactions outside the country in response to the invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/1dU8GfAxwy
Videos verified by The New York Times appear to show Russian-backed separatists in a small town in eastern Ukraine firing on protesters, striking one in the leg. https://t.co/paZ4nDtdWF

While technology giants like Apple and luxury retailers like Hermès have quickly moved to pause sales or shutter stores in Russia over the invasion of Ukraine, fast-food chains like McDonald’s and Yum Brands have remained open — and largely silent. https://t.co/6bNBftdyST

Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that the Biden administration has asked Congress to approve $2.75 billion in humanitarian assistance for vulnerable communities inside Ukraine and refugee services in neighboring countries. https://t.co/m66ls7GKXw https://t.co/JcPicZ2N9X

In Opinion
"In just over one week of hellish war, Ukrainians revealed themselves to be some of the bravest people in the world," writes Anastasiia Lapatina, a Ukrainian reporter at The Kyiv Independent. "We will not surrender and we will not capitulate." https://t.co/DyLSdWxWXb

People from the city of Irpin rushed to Kyiv’s central railway station on Friday to flee heavy fighting. "It's terrible and terrifying," one resident said in tears. "We have to leave our relatives, our father, our brother and, just for what?" https://t.co/GFJta7wGO4 https://t.co/ko9pHMIaz0

Oleksandr Abramenko, the Ukrainian skier whose hug with a Russian rival at the Beijing Olympics was widely shared, has been sleeping in a Kyiv garage for several days now with his wife and 2-year-old son. "The air attack siren is constantly on," he said. https://t.co/gidPH4S8jF

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spoke with U.S. Congress members via Zoom on Saturday, asking them for more jets and again asking for a no-fly zone over his country, which Western governments have rebuffed as all but impossible. https://t.co/zzc6LqDGPH

Allied nations are discussing how to secure Ukraine's line of succession if President Volodymyr Zelensky is captured or killed. The concerns are primarily about ensuring an independent government of some form, even if Russia installs puppet leadership. https://t.co/BvafNkveep

Some U.S. veterans are looking to join the fight in Ukraine, emboldened by President Volodymyr Zelensky's call for volunteers, though the U.S. has long discouraged its citizens from becoming freelance fighters because of the risk of unintended escalation. https://t.co/OVDawElcBR
